Bug.Summery: Classcast exception from Registers View
Bug.WithStack:
Build: 20050420
Registers View throws a class cast exception when trying to fetch registers.
java.lang.ClassCastException: SampleRegisterGroup incompatible with org/eclipse/debug/core/model/IVariable at java.lang.Throwable.<init>(Throwable.java) at java.lang.Throwable.<init>(Throwable.java) at java.lang.ClassCastException.<init>(ClassCastException.java:54) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.elements.adapters.DeferredStackFrame.fetchDeferred Children(DeferredStackFrame.java:58) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.views.RemoteTreeContentManager$3.run (RemoteTreeContentManager.java:264) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java) Sorry... actually running debug ui from HEAD.
Fixed. Changes to DeferredStackFrame and DeferredRegisterViewStackFrame. Please verify, Samantha. Verified with changes from HEAD.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build: 20050420
Registers View throws a class cast exception when trying to fetch registers.
Sorry... actually running debug ui from HEAD.
Fixed. Changes to DeferredStackFrame and DeferredRegisterViewStackFrame. Please verify, Samantha. Verified with changes from HEAD.

Bug.Summery: NPE in OperationHistroy while shutting down Eclipse
Bug.WithStack:
I20050420-1200 & latest command and workbench.ui code
Did the following
- execute a rename method refactoring form the editor which affected several files
- did some undo/redo (don't know how often)
- exit eclispe.
The problem is that site.getShell() == null since the workbench is already gone
Thread [System Bundle Shutdown] (Suspended (exception NullPointerException)) UndoActionHandler(OperationHistoryActionHandler).historyNotification(OperationHistoryEvent) line: 261 DefaultOperationHistory.notifyRemoved(IUndoableOperation) line: 926 DefaultOperationHistory.internalRemove(IUndoableOperation) line: 751 DefaultOperationHistory.replaceOperation(IUndoableOperation, IUndoableOperation[]) line: 1104 TriggeredOperations.remove(IUndoableOperation) line: 83 TriggeredOperations.removeContext(IUndoContext) line: 108 DefaultOperationHistory.flushUndo(IUndoContext) line: 544 DefaultOperationHistory.dispose(IUndoContext, boolean, boolean, boolean) line: 253 WorkbenchOperationSupport.dispose() line: 55 WorkbenchPlugin.stop(BundleContext) line: 893 BundleContextImpl$3.run() line: 1035 AccessController.doPrivileged(PrivilegedExceptionAction<T>) line: not available [native method] BundleContextImpl.stop() line: 1031 BundleHost.stopWorker(boolean) line: 402 BundleHost(AbstractBundle).stop() line: 410 BundleStopper.basicStopBundles() line: 73 BundleStopper.stopBundles() line: 62 EclipseAdaptor.frameworkStopping(BundleContext) line: 695 Framework.shutdown() line: 502 SystemBundle$1.run() line: 171 Thread.run() line: 595 Updated the historyNotification method to obtain the display from the workbench and check for null display before running the asyncExec.
Should appear in builds > 20050425 (including the 0426 nightly build) however the map file is already updated for I20050426 so it likely will not be in the i-build. verified on I20050509-2010 by shutting down after performing some refactoring>rename undo tests
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20050420-1200 & latest command and workbench.ui code
Did the following
- execute a rename method refactoring form the editor which affected several files
- did some undo/redo (don't know how often)
- exit eclispe.
The problem is that site.getShell() == null since the workbench is already gone
Thread [System Bundle Shutdown] (Suspended (exception NullPointerException)) UndoActionHandler(OperationHistoryActionHandler).historyNotification(OperationHistoryEvent) line: 261 DefaultOperationHistory.notifyRemoved(IUndoableOperation) line: 926 DefaultOperationHistory.internalRemove(IUndoableOperation) line: 751 DefaultOperationHistory.replaceOperation(IUndoableOperation, IUndoableOperation[]) line: 1104 TriggeredOperations.remove(IUndoableOperation) line: 83 TriggeredOperations.removeContext(IUndoContext) line: 108 DefaultOperationHistory.flushUndo(IUndoContext) line: 544 DefaultOperationHistory.dispose(IUndoContext, boolean, boolean, boolean) line: 253 WorkbenchOperationSupport.dispose() line: 55 WorkbenchPlugin.stop(BundleContext) line: 893 BundleContextImpl$3.run() line: 1035 AccessController.doPrivileged(PrivilegedExceptionAction<T>) line: not available [native method] BundleContextImpl.stop() line: 1031 BundleHost.stopWorker(boolean) line: 402 BundleHost(AbstractBundle).stop() line: 410 BundleStopper.basicStopBundles() line: 73 BundleStopper.stopBundles() line: 62 EclipseAdaptor.frameworkStopping(BundleContext) line: 695 Framework.shutdown() line: 502 SystemBundle$1.run() line: 171 Thread.run() line: 595 Updated the historyNotification method to obtain the display from the workbench and check for null display before running the asyncExec.
Should appear in builds > 20050425 (including the 0426 nightly build) however the map file is already updated for I20050426 so it likely will not be in the i-build. verified on I20050509-2010 by shutting down after performing some refactoring>rename undo tests

Bug.Summery: [printing] Allow printing from Javadoc view
Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse should allow printing from views other than the editor. for example, in the Java perspective, i would like to print from the javadoc view. This would need to be a plan item - it crosses many components. MvM? This seems like it should be a request on the JavaDoc view. I'm not sure this is a generally useful feature on a view, e.g. package explorer, outline, debug stack etc...
Are there other views that you would like to see this on? Please reopen after replying to comment 2. (In reply to comment #2) > This seems like it should be a request on the JavaDoc view. I'm not sure this > is a generally useful feature on a view, e.g. package explorer, outline, debug > stack etc... > > Are there other views that you would like to see this on?
Other views for which printing ability would be: console, declaration, tasks, problems.
For the last 2 ( and any other table base view ), an export to a spreadsheet format would be more helpful.
I don't think there will be a general printing or spreadsheet support. Please file enhancement requests for each component.
I'll treat this one as request for Javadoc printing.

Bug.Summery: IJavaStackFrame.isVarargs() named inconsistently
Bug.WithStack:
20050419
We renamed Method.isVarargs() to Method.isVarArgs(), however, we added a new method IJavaStackFrame.isVarargs(). We should ensure that these methods are consistently named. Fixed. Changes to JDIStackFrame and IJavaStackFrame. Technically, this is an API change, but it does not affect any clients in the SDK, and it is a new method in 3.1, and this a change that we want to make. Please verify, Luc. Verified.

20050419
We renamed Method.isVarargs() to Method.isVarArgs(), however, we added a new method IJavaStackFrame.isVarargs(). We should ensure that these methods are consistently named. Fixed. Please verify, Luc. Verified.

Bug.Summery: (Plat) datacollection build has non-existent dependencies

Lines.Line: 1. Change the makefiles to pick up the CBE stuff from an env var relative
location, say %CBE_HOME%. This is how the Xerces-c dependency is handled. It
let's me cobble together a Xerces-c environment anyway and anywhere I can, yet
still have the build work. CBE should be the same.
2. Put %CBE_HOME%\CImpl on the include path for the modules that require it
from *inside the makefiles* instead of making me set it in my environment. You
know you need it, so include it. Ditto with the link requirement.
3. Update org.eclipse.hyades.datacollection\README.txt to include the new
requirement on CBE. This should be done whether or not you plan to fix the CBE
references to be env var relative. Don't forget to tell the poor suckers which
of the 167 Hyades projects it lives in.
1. Get org.eclipse.hyades.logging.native (the rest of the world doesn't know
that's where CommonBaseEvents.h, etc. lives).
2. Move org.eclipse.hyades.logging.native under
org.eclipse.hyades.datacollection and change it's name to "cbe". This becomes
CBE_HOME.
3. Build cbe.
4. Put %CBE_HOME%\Cimpl in your INCLUDE path. (Or fix the makefiles!)
5. Put %CBE_HOME%\Winbuild on your LIB path. (Or fix the makefiles)

Bug.WithStack:
I wish every once in awhile you guys would trying building RAServer and the agents from the command line outside your own build framework so you could discover how painful this is for the rest of the world. And please don't tell me I'm not supposed to use the makefiles. There is no technical reason they can't be made general. Further, there are no more instructions for setting up your env to build from Visual Studio than there are for building from the command line, so that stance does not set you free. OK, rant off. Here's the problem:
The datacollection build now requires the native CBE headers and libraries, with never a whisper of documentation about where they're supposed to come from. It was loads o' fun trying to figure that out.
It is not adequate to grab the CBE native SDK from the TPTP download page because that only includes the dll and the datacollection build requires the .lib file.
But wait, there's more! The Release build not only needs the lib file, it wants it to be located in ..\..\..\cbe, which translates into org.eclipse.hyades.datacollection\cbe, which doesn't exist.
If you try to do a Debug build, the makefiles don't use the relative path at all. Rather, it assumes the right thing is on your LIB env var. At least that's better than requiring some weird made-up directory.
My suggestions are:
1. Change the makefiles to pick up the CBE stuff from an env var relative location, say %CBE_HOME%. This is how the Xerces-c dependency is handled. It let's me cobble together a Xerces-c environment anyway and anywhere I can, yet still have the build work. CBE should be the same.
2. Put %CBE_HOME%\CImpl on the include path for the modules that require it from *inside the makefiles* instead of making me set it in my environment. You know you need it, so include it. Ditto with the link requirement.
3. Update org.eclipse.hyades.datacollection\README.txt to include the new requirement on CBE. This should be done whether or not you plan to fix the CBE references to be env var relative. Don't forget to tell the poor suckers which of the 167 Hyades projects it lives in.
If you're not going to fix the makefile references, then you will need to include more information in README.txt, like the need to copy org.eclipse.hyades.logging.native into org.eclipse.hyades.datacollection\cbe. (I hope you're blushing by now).
Here are the things I found I needed to do and which I would recommend using as a starting place for updating README.txt.
1. Get org.eclipse.hyades.logging.native (the rest of the world doesn't know that's where CommonBaseEvents.h, etc. lives). 2. Move org.eclipse.hyades.logging.native under org.eclipse.hyades.datacollection and change it's name to "cbe". This becomes CBE_HOME. 3. Build cbe. 4. Put %CBE_HOME%\Cimpl in your INCLUDE path. (Or fix the makefiles!) 5. Put %CBE_HOME%\Winbuild on your LIB path. (Or fix the makefiles)
And, yes, that funny sound you hear is my teeth grinding... Moving to TPTP 4.0i4 per today call. The CommonBaseEvent.lib file is now included in the Native Common Base Event SDK under defect https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=95694. Updated Agent Controller readme (org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agentcontroller\src- native\collection\README.txt) with sufficient to build the Agent Controller code on both Windows and Linux (IA32). Modifications to Agent Controller make files will be completed for the new Agent Controller code base under a future defect.
Checked-in org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agentcontroller\src- native\collection\README.txt to TPTP CVS (HEAD) on June 7, 2005. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

I wish every once in awhile you guys would trying building RAServer and the agents from the command line outside your own build framework so you could discover how painful this is for the rest of the world. And please don't tell me I'm not supposed to use the makefiles. There is no technical reason they can't be made general. Further, there are no more instructions for setting up your env to build from Visual Studio than there are for building from the command line, so that stance does not set you free. OK, rant off. Bug.Summery: (Plat) ClassCastException while opening Sequence Diagram view
Bug.WithStack:
In a higher product, we have a new collection mode, where the trace model is being loaded with aggregated method invocations directly (as compared to the current available modes: statistics vs full graph). In this mode, the only views that behave correctly are the execution statistics views. The other views either fail to open at all (sequence diagram) or open correctly with insufficient data (execution flow).
One of the problems with some of these views is that they expect that method invocations in a process be TRCFullMethodInvocations. Current trace model supports TRCFullMethodInvocation as well as TRCAggregatedMethodInvocation. Hence these views would have to qualify the invocation list correctly and disable themselves if they are not able to handle the list.
The invocation list can either be Full MIs or Aggregated MIs; not both. Fixed in 3.3 and 4.0. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Current trace model supports TRCFullMethodInvocation as well as TRCAggregatedMethodInvocation. Hence these views would have to qualify the invocation list correctly and disable themselves if they are not able to handle the list.
The invocation list can either be Full MIs or Aggregated MIs; not both. Fixed in 3.3 and 4.0. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: ANT Build failing
Bug.WithStack:
In the "Web Services Required Jars Download Instructions" section by Keith Chong, the ANT script for copying the required plugin files is failing because the jar file for (Web Services Inspection Language for Java) wsil4.jar is actually downloaded as a zip file and not a jar from the URL http://awwebx04.alphaworks.ibm.com/wsil4j/wsil4j.jar.
This needs to be extracted and jarred for the ant script to run successfully. These are packaged with WTP now. Please verify and close. Marking as verified as I know this issue is fixed (or correctly categorized). If, as originator, you disagree or still see, please re-open, or open a new bug.
Thanks very much for reporting and helping make WTP better.
verified

In the "Web Services Required Jars Download Instructions" section by Keith Chong, the ANT script for copying the required plugin files is failing because the jar file for (Web Services Inspection Language for Java) wsil4.jar is actually downloaded as a zip file and not a jar from the URL http://awwebx04.alphaworks.ibm.com/wsil4j/wsil4j.jar.
This needs to be extracted and jarred for the ant script to run successfully. These are packaged with WTP now. Please verify and close. Marking as verified as I know this issue is fixed (or correctly categorized). If, as originator, you disagree or still see, please re-open, or open a new bug.
Thanks very much for reporting and helping make WTP better.
verified

Bug.Summery: Attaching Source to j3dcore.jar breaks java.library.path
Bug.WithStack:
I have been developing a Java3D application with eclipse and for the most part it works great! Except, when I try to attach the Java3D source to one of the J3D library jar files, e.g. j3dcore.jar, java.library.path breaks. This is the error I get:
Exception: in thread "main" java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: no J3D in java.library.path
When I tried removing the source from the jar files via the project Properties Java Build Path Libraries editor, I still get the error.
It appears that attaching the source introduces a bug that cannot be reversed.
Only when I remove the .metadata directory from the workspace, then rebuild the project, does the bug go away.
Please help! If this bug can be fixed then Java3D development via Eclipse would be a beautiful thing! thanks Just to clarify; When I say "attach Java3D source to the j3dcore.jar file", I ment the Java3D API source code from: https://j3d-core.dev.java.net/ So that I can debug my application, and learn how the j3d api works. thanks
Have further narrowed this down to: org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs file In the directory: .metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime/.settings directory in the workspace directory. I have still further narrowed this down to a relationship between the org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs file and the org.eclipse.jdt.launching.prefs file. When setting the source code for the j3dcore.jar file, the org.eclipse.jdt.launching.prefs file seems to be overwriting the org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs file.
I tried adding -Djava.path.library=/System/Library/Java/Extensions as a VM runtime argument, but it seems to be ignored. Even though the java3d jnilib files are in the above path, I still get the can't find J3D in java.library.path error.
Can someone please respond to this bug report, as I posted the orginal a week ago?
Thanks Moving to JDT/Debug Which version of Eclipse are you using? and is this really applicable for MacOSX only? works fine for me. I downloaded the src for j3dcore and set the source attachement to the src/classes/share directory. Everything still worked fine. Used from sample code from http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-12-1998/jw-12-media-p4.html for testing. Did not need to set java.library.path at all. I am using version 3.0.2 I haven't been able to test it on another platform. All I know is it is happening on Mac OS X.
thanks
(In reply to comment #5) > Which version of Eclipse are you using? and is this really applicable for > MacOSX only? (In reply to comment #7) > I am using version 3.0.2 > I haven't been able to test it on another platform. > All I know is it is happening on Mac OS X. > > thanks > > (In reply to comment #5) > > Which version of Eclipse are you using? and is this really applicable for > > MacOSX only?

Did you attach the source as a directory of files, or a source code jar file? Please try attaching source for java as well, which is what I'm doing. I'm wondering eclipse cannot handle more than one source attachment? Did you test on Mac OS X, or another platform? thanks

Bug.Summery: Bookmark icon in toolbar doesn't work in Opera8
Bug.WithStack:
When you start Help System in Infocenter mode, and identify Opera as MSIE6.0, bookmark icon will appear in the content toolbar. But when you click it, nothing happen, the page will not be bookmarked. In the Infocenter bookmarking is supported only by adding to Internet Explorer favorites. Obviously Opera it is not quite IE it pretends to be.
Fixed by removing the "Bookmark document" toolbar button when Opera. Thanks Konrad! It seems that, for Opera which is identified as MSIE6.0, both method isIE() and isOpera() are return true! It's a little strange. :-)
Bug.WithOutStack:
When you start Help System in Infocenter mode, and identify Opera as MSIE6.0, bookmark icon will appear in the content toolbar. But when you click it, nothing happen, the page will not be bookmarked. In the Infocenter bookmarking is supported only by adding to Internet Explorer favorites. Obviously Opera it is not quite IE it pretends to be.
Fixed by removing the "Bookmark document" toolbar button when Opera. Thanks Konrad! It seems that, for Opera which is identified as MSIE6.0, both method isIE() and isOpera() are return true! It's a little strange. :-)

Bug.Summery: Context search for Class does not work

Lines.Line: 1-Open the SB.h file in the project1 project.
2-Highlight the class SB name
3-Right click on the highlight and select All References->Workspace from the
context menu.

Bug.WithStack:
OS: windows XP Language: Traditional Chinese Build level: 3.0.0 M6 JDK version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 SP1a Test case #: CS18[I18N79]
Summary: DBCS3.1: Context search for Class does not work
Steps to recreate problem (as described in the document) 1-Open the SB.h file in the project1 project. 2-Highlight the class SB name 3-Right click on the highlight and select All References->Workspace from the context menu.
....
Error: The Search View shows that 0 References exist in the Workspace. Precisely, it displays:
::SB - 0 References in Workspace
Expected Result:
There should be 4 references: the constructor and destructor, defined in SB.h, and the 2 other functions, defined in SB.cpp. Created attachment 20334 an image of the search results Created attachment 20335 the SB.cpp file Created attachment 20336 the SB.h file Created attachment 20337 the main.cpp file Tanya, can you verify that the test case includes a project with the indexer enabled? This looks like a default project (i.e. no indexer enabled which will lead to all searches returning 0 results). After choosing the "Original C/C++ Indexer" and checking the "Enable C/C++ Indexing" box, the results are a little better.
However, in the attached SB.h and SB.cpp files there is a function called SB::add, which I have tested to run properly. This SB::add function, when searched from the SB.h file, results in 0 matches(there should be 1 match). On the other hand, searching for SB::hello results in 1 match (the expected result).
The difference between the 2 cases is that the SB::add is referenced by SB::hello, whereas SB::hello is referenced by main. Because SB::hello is referenced by main, the search results in 1 match, but since SB:add is not referenced by main, the search results in 0 matches. However, the Context Searcher does not count the 1 refernce to SB::add located in SB::hello.
Thus, I believe that there is still incorrect operation evident in the Context Searcher.
After trying DOM AST C/C++ Indexer instead of Original C/C++ Indexer, the Context Search for SB::add now works fine.
I will assume that this is an external problem associated only with the Original C/C++ Indexer, since I get normal operation when using DOM AST C/C++ Indexer.
This can be considered closed. This problem was entirely a result of project settings.
Bug.WithOutStack:
OS: windows XP Language: Traditional Chinese Build level: 3.0.0 M6 JDK version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 SP1a Test case #: CS18[I18N79]
Summary: DBCS3.1: Context search for Class does not work
Steps to recreate problem (as described in the document) 1-Open the SB.h file in the project1 project. 2-Highlight the class SB name 3-Right click on the highlight and select All References->Workspace from the context menu.
....
Error: The Search View shows that 0 References exist in the Workspace. Precisely, it displays:
::SB - 0 References in Workspace
Expected Result:
There should be 4 references: the constructor and destructor, defined in SB.h, and the 2 other functions, defined in SB.cpp. Created attachment 20334 an image of the search results Created attachment 20335 the SB.cpp file Created attachment 20336 the SB.h file Created attachment 20337 the main.cpp file Tanya, can you verify that the test case includes a project with the indexer enabled? This looks like a default project (i.e. no indexer enabled which will lead to all searches returning 0 results). After choosing the "Original C/C++ Indexer" and checking the "Enable C/C++ Indexing" box, the results are a little better.
However, in the attached SB.h and SB.cpp files there is a function called SB::add, which I have tested to run properly. This SB::add function, when searched from the SB.h file, results in 0 matches(there should be 1 match). On the other hand, searching for SB::hello results in 1 match (the expected result).
The difference between the 2 cases is that the SB::add is referenced by SB::hello, whereas SB::hello is referenced by main. Because SB::hello is referenced by main, the search results in 1 match, but since SB:add is not referenced by main, the search results in 0 matches. However, the Context Searcher does not count the 1 refernce to SB::add located in SB::hello.
Thus, I believe that there is still incorrect operation evident in the Context Searcher.
After trying DOM AST C/C++ Indexer instead of Original C/C++ Indexer, the Context Search for SB::add now works fine.
I will assume that this is an external problem associated only with the Original C/C++ Indexer, since I get normal operation when using DOM AST C/C++ Indexer.
This can be considered closed. This problem was entirely a result of project settings.

Bug.Summery: In Opera8, when click "Restore" button in toolar, help system will become a blank

Lines.Line: 1. Launch IEHS in IC mode on your machine;
2. Open Opera8 and navigate to http://localhost:8888/help;
3. Click "Maximize" button in navigation toolbar or content toolbar to
maximize the frame;
4. Click "Restore" button to restore the frame.

Bug.WithStack:
Steps to reproduce: 1. Launch IEHS in IC mode on your machine; 2. Open Opera8 and navigate to http://localhost:8888/help; 3. Click "Maximize" button in navigation toolbar or content toolbar to maximize the frame; 4. Click "Restore" button to restore the frame.
After clicking "Restore", Help System will become a blank frame. Created attachment 20338 I try to fix it, please check, thanks. Many things don't work in Opera exactly as in IE or Mozilla, and we do not fully support each browser quirks. All such browsers have a basic UI presented. If Opera identifies itself as Opera it gets directed to simplified help UI. If Opera identifies itself as Mozilla it gets directed to simplified help UI. If Opera identifies itself as IE it gets directed to advanced help UI, for Internet explorer and Mozilla. We can leave this as is and let Opera experience some of advanced fuctionality with bugs, or direct it simplified UI in that case. I prefer, the user decides by setting their "identify as" as they want.
Hi Konrad!
We understand your answer.
I think what the real underlying requested enhancement our teams have is to have the Bookmark icon for infocenter mode have the same user experience for all browsers in which we support advanced help UI
Background history: Prior to Eclipse 3.0, there was no Bookmark icon for the help system when running in infocenter mode. The teams that my team supports had requested the ability to have the same bookmarking user experience in standalone and integrated modes (the Bookmark view and Bookmark icon) to be present in infocenter mode. They requested this because the bookmark functionality was very convenient to bookmark a topic to that bookmark view and infocenter users were requesting that function.
We opened a request for enhancement, but it was late in the Eclipse 3.0 release cycle and the function that made it into the release was to add the bookmark icon to the advanced UI for IE only, and send the user request to add the bookmark to the IE Favorites menu.
Now, it appears as if there is a function (the Bookmarking user function) that is only for users that use the infocenter in IE and not in any other supported browser that does advanced UI (Mozilla, Firefox). And this difference then shows up as a "bug" in Opera when Opera is set to identify as IE.
Given that history, I believe that the right goal to achieve likely goes back to the original one: from a user experience point of view, have a consistent treatment of bookmarking that is consistent across modes (integrated, standalone, infocenter) and across supported browsers for advanced UI (Mozilla, IE, Firefox). This consistent treatment might be provided as the capability for the same Bookmark view/Bookmark icon user experience that is in standalone/integrated to the infocenter mode.
Your thoughts on whether that is the right goal to achieve? User experience for bookmarking a topic consistent across modes and advanced UI browsers?
Ooops, ignore my comment just above. I commented on the wrong bug. Meant to put this on the bookmark one, before I saw Konrad's other comment there.
My apologies! --Lee Anne

Bug.Summery: Allow to filter classes in type hierarchy view
Bug.WithStack:
When we view a type hierarchy for a super senior type[Like Object] or interface[Like Serializable] we will be presented with a big list of sub classes. It would be better if there is a way to filter these classes. may be based on package structure.
Doing so would also helpfull to expore perticular package, ex. if we need to find which all classes in java.util.* implement Clonable interface. To see the type hierarchy for a package simply open a type hierarchy on the package. To do so, selected the package and execute "Open Type Hiararchy" from the context menu.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When we view a type hierarchy for a super senior type[Like Object] or interface[Like Serializable] we will be presented with a big list of sub classes. It would be better if there is a way to filter these classes. may be based on package structure.
Doing so would also helpfull to expore perticular package, ex. if we need to find which all classes in java.util.* implement Clonable interface. To see the type hierarchy for a package simply open a type hierarchy on the package. To do so, selected the package and execute "Open Type Hiararchy" from the context menu.

Bug.Summery: GenericServerBehaviour.setupLaunch missing method call

source_code.code: The GenericServerBehaviour.setupLaunch() method should invoke setMode(launchMode);

Bug.WithStack:
The GenericServerBehaviour.setupLaunch() method should invoke setMode(launchMode); If it does not do this, the started server will always appear in 'run' mode. With this method call, you can start the server in debug mode, and it will show that way in the servers view. Thank you very much for this one, I fixed it, it is in the HEAD. Hi Gorkem,
Given that this is a safe & minor change, please feel free to tag for the I/M build if you think it's appropriate. Released for next I build. Changed Version field given new release numbering.
Closing old bugs that haven't had any activity in a couple months. If this problem has not been verified or you still have problems, please open a new bug.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The GenericServerBehaviour.setupLaunch() method should invoke setMode(launchMode); If it does not do this, the started server will always appear in 'run' mode. With this method call, you can start the server in debug mode, and it will show that way in the servers view. Thank you very much for this one, I fixed it, it is in the HEAD. Hi Gorkem,
Given that this is a safe & minor change, please feel free to tag for the I/M build if you think it's appropriate. Released for next I build. Changed Version field given new release numbering.

Bug.Summery: Per-Project "Build Automatically" option
Bug.WithStack:
Whether to enable automatic building should better be able to configure in a per-project basis.
Coz it's common that we want automatic build in general but not some of the project. But if we enable automatic build in the project menu, every opened / to-be-opened project will follow. Moving to Platform Resources for comment.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 3033 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
Whether to enable automatic building should better be able to configure in a per-project basis.
Coz it's common that we want automatic build in general but not some of the project. But if we enable automatic build in the project menu, every opened / to-be-opened project will follow. Moving to Platform Resources for comment.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 3033 ***

Bug.Summery: [consistency] setSelection(new Item[] {null}) inconsistent
Bug.WithStack:
We should be able to add the following test to the JUnit tests for List, Tree, Table and TabFolder, and have something reasonable and consistent happen: xxx.setSelection(new XxxItem[] {null});
For example: table.setSelection(new TableItem[]{null}); assertEquals(0, table.getSelectionCount());
Note that currently the methods: Table.setSelection(TableItem[] items) TabFolder.setSelection(TabItem[] items) both fail in wierd places (indexOf throws an IllegalArgumentException).
Currently, these other 2 similar methods ignore null items and can have an empty selection (on Windows, anyhow): Tree.setSelection(TreeItem[] items) List.setSelection(String[] items)
The javadoc for Tree, List, and Table (but not TabFolder) says: * Items that are not in the receiver are ignored. which we could interpret to mean "null items are ignored".
Note that this might not be a straightforward change in Table, because it is possible that GTK Tables cannot have no selection... Billy, is this true?
For that matter, can any TabFolder have no selection?
Bug.WithOutStack:
We should be able to add the following test to the JUnit tests for List, Tree, Table and TabFolder, and have something reasonable and consistent happen: xxx.setSelection(new XxxItem[] {null});
For example: table.setSelection(new TableItem[]{null}); assertEquals(0, table.getSelectionCount());
Note that currently the methods: Table.setSelection(TableItem[] items) TabFolder.setSelection(TabItem[] items) both fail in wierd places (indexOf throws an IllegalArgumentException).
Currently, these other 2 similar methods ignore null items and can have an empty selection (on Windows, anyhow): Tree.setSelection(TreeItem[] items) List.setSelection(String[] items)
The javadoc for Tree, List, and Table (but not TabFolder) says: * Items that are not in the receiver are ignored. which we could interpret to mean "null items are ignored".
Note that this might not be a straightforward change in Table, because it is possible that GTK Tables cannot have no selection... Billy, is this true?
For that matter, can any TabFolder have no selection?

Bug.Summery: [editor] CTRL+V/SHIFT+INS not working for pasting from external applications
Bug.WithStack:
On windows it's common to use CTRL+V and SHIFT+INS to copy and past text into text fields.
The PDE editor uses some special fields or intercepts key bindings. However, the shortcuts do not work in text fields on the Extension page for editing extenion properties (attributes).
Example: Open PDE editor -> Extensions -> org.eclipse.ui.bindings -> new "key" -> select "commandId"
-> now open an external editor (notepad or textpad) -> enter some text there, select this text and press CTRL+C/X or SHIFT+DEL -> switch back to PDE editor -> try to paste this into "commandId" with CTRL+V or SHIFT+INS -> does not work -> right click on the field "commandId", select "Paste" -> does work
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 87263 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
On windows it's common to use CTRL+V and SHIFT+INS to copy and past text into text fields.
The PDE editor uses some special fields or intercepts key bindings. However, the shortcuts do not work in text fields on the Extension page for editing extenion properties (attributes).
Example: Open PDE editor -> Extensions -> org.eclipse.ui.bindings -> new "key" -> select "commandId"
-> now open an external editor (notepad or textpad) -> enter some text there, select this text and press CTRL+C/X or SHIFT+DEL -> switch back to PDE editor -> try to paste this into "commandId" with CTRL+V or SHIFT+INS -> does not work -> right click on the field "commandId", select "Paste" -> does work
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 87263 ***

Bug.Summery: The preferences label for COMPILER_PB_UNUSED_PARAMETER_WHEN_IMPLEMENTING_ABSTRACT is confusing
Bug.WithStack: The preferences label for COMPILER_PB_UNUSED_PARAMETER_WHEN_(IMPLEMENTING_ABSTRACT|OVERRIDING_CONCRETE) is confusing. It says "Check overriding and implementing methods" - and doesn't make it clear if the compiler will or will not ignore this warning when implementing/overriding methods. It should say something like "Report even when implementing or overriding methods". won't fix
Bug.WithOutStack: The preferences label for COMPILER_PB_UNUSED_PARAMETER_WHEN_(IMPLEMENTING_ABSTRACT|OVERRIDING_CONCRETE) is confusing. It says "Check overriding and implementing methods" - and doesn't make it clear if the compiler will or will not ignore this warning when implementing/overriding methods. It should say something like "Report even when implementing or overriding methods". won't fix

Bug.Summery: [compiler] On a "duplicate variable" compiler error, link to the original definition
Bug.WithStack:
When there's a duplicate variable error - either local or a member - each redifinition should have a link to the next definition. Take this as a test case: class Test { int i; // line 2 int i; // line 3 int i; // line 4 }; // for c++ compatibility, see below
This is how g++ handles the above Test: test.cpp:3: error: declaration of `int Test::i' test.cpp:2: error: conflicts with previous declaration `int Test::i' test.cpp:4: error: declaration of `int Test::i' test.cpp:2: error: conflicts with previous declaration `int Test::i'
When this output is displayed in a supporting IDE, the user can easily jump to the first definition.
Eclipse simply reports, on each of lines 2-4, "Duplicate field Test.i".
I suggest adding a quickfix to each redefinition: go to next definition. Selecting this quickfix will not fix anything, but will rather jump to the next line where the variable was defined. The last definition will link to the first one. Alternatively, make all redefinitions link to the first definition. This approach (like what g++ does) makes sense, but is not compatible (it seems) with the Eclipse Java compiler (it also shows the error on the first - legal - definition). Moving to core for consideration. Moving to JDT/UI for quickfix suggestion.
A quick fix should fix something, not jump to a location. I think the suggestion to enhance the compiler warning is good: ''i' already defined on line 20. We could improve error message by reporting on what line is the conflicting declaration. Created attachment 51599 Proposed fix Created attachment 51600 Regression tests updated For the quickfix, I would suggest a rename operation on the duplicate field. I am not convinced by the proposed fix.
Usually duplicates are complained against by flagging all dups, as we do already. What if you have 3 duplicates... which one is denoted by the other line ? any/first ?
Quickfix can easily be provided by walking the DOM AST. We may offer some helpers, though I don't see why we would need to. I added the quick fix that suggests to rename > 20061009 Quick fix doesn't need to know anything about the other declarations. This request is purely to help users finding the problem.
I think the problem description should mention only the first declaration. Other duplications are not interesting (and its also not that common that you have multiple duplication)
If adding this quickfix is good enough and we don't plan to change the error message, then we should close it. Philipe, any comment? That's not what I said. The quick fix does not solve the problem this bug was opened on. I just added the quickfix that you suggested in comment 7. So if you are on a field/variable that is marked as duplicated, we propose a suggestion to rename this field. The user still doesn't know why this field is duplicated, say where the first declaration is located. The first field duplicate also carries a problem as well. Only for local variables we only blame the subsequent occurrences.
If we did add some support for denoting other place in the code elsewhere, we should generalize to other problems as well, and UI should offer ways to take advantage of this (jump to other location, or browse them both in parallel etc...).
Could be nice, but I don't think we have the resources to go after these presently. This is why I am not convinced that a ad-hoc solution here would be what we would want in the future.
What if there is an easy way on a duplicate var to find other conflicting occurrences as an action/quickfix, isn't it all needed ? This doesn't require to change our error message, and introduce line numbers which we never had anywhere until now. Still edging. As we start with rich hovers (on the 3.3 plan), we will also be able to provide a link that jumps to the given line. But the information would still have to come from jdt.core.
I think Oliviers suggested patch is really good and a big plus for the user. Why not try that and if we find it isn't good enough, improve it as we go? First of all, the patch should concern only local variables. We don't want to add a line number inside the error message. This would make it awkwards regarding to all other messages. Would a warning on the first local be an improvement? This warning would say that this local has a duplicate. We would keep an error on all duplicate locals as we do right now. Re: comment 13 We could still record alternate information in the marker (extra argument). Just phrasing the error message with line number position feels awkward. Martin,
I'd like to solve this one once for all. So please let me know what information you need wrt the comment 15. I'm not really a fan of using the problem arguments from our code and I think we eliminated all usages in our quick fix code. Problem is of course that they are unspec'ed and avoiding them makes your life much easier. I still think it makes sense to add the line information into the problem message. Rich hovers probably won't make it to 3.3, so no needs there.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When there's a duplicate variable error - either local or a member - each redifinition should have a link to the next definition. Take this as a test case: class Test { int i; // line 2 int i; // line 3 int i; // line 4 }; // for c++ compatibility, see below
This is how g++ handles the above Test: test.cpp:3: error: declaration of `int Test::i' test.cpp:2: error: conflicts with previous declaration `int Test::i' test.cpp:4: error: declaration of `int Test::i' test.cpp:2: error: conflicts with previous declaration `int Test::i'

Bug.Summery: [Functionality] PATH set in ExecutionEnvironmentAdapter changes path on Lin
Bug.WithStack:
I try to change the PATH system variable for a remote test agent running on Linux, from a test client running in a Windows workbench. The remote Linux PATH must be set indiviually for different users running the application, and must therefore be set dynamically.
I set the PATH system variable in the ExecutionEnvironmentAdapter:
ExecutionEnivronmentAdapter::setupExecutionEnvironment():
IOrderedProperty pathProperty = env.getEnvByName("PATH"); String newPath = "/foo/bar"; pathProperty.prependValue(newPath); env.setEnv(pathProperty);
But on the remote Linux server side the PATH variable does not get changed, but path (with small letters) gets changed instead. So the test agent cannot launch the external process. Runtime.exec() gives IOException <command> not found.
A workaround seems to be to start the Remote Agent Controller from a Linux shell that uses path instead of PATH. Moving the tptp.test-inbox@eclipse.org bugzillas over to the new default owner of Test.Execution. Forwarding to Joe to investigate/assign appropriately Moving to execution framework component, as this is not a test specific problem
Per the 6/8/2005 platform call, this can now be moved to 4.1 (someone with access, lease move it)-- for 4.0, if a readme entry is needed to explain the workaround, please open a new defect to address this.
[ sizing = 2 days ] cleaning up assignees As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. Since this defect is more than 2 years old, it may be no longer relevant. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this defect is resolved as WONTFIX. If this defect is still relevant and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: [assist] Classes suggested in implements clause
Bug.WithStack:
20050426
Do a code assist in public class MyMapEntry implements Ent// code assist here {} You get interfaces 5 interfaces and 10 classes.
Obviously you can't insert classes here and the suggested classes also don't contain an inner (static) interface. The interface I want is not even in the list ('Map.Entry')
Even this case seems quite special, it shows up in the new type wizard (interface table) where we also use the code assist infrastructure. Fixed.
See bug 94965 comment 1. Verified on build I20050526-2000-win32.
Bug.WithOutStack:
20050426
Do a code assist in public class MyMapEntry implements Ent// code assist here {} You get interfaces 5 interfaces and 10 classes.
Obviously you can't insert classes here and the suggested classes also don't contain an inner (static) interface. The interface I want is not even in the list ('Map.Entry')
Even this case seems quite special, it shows up in the new type wizard (interface table) where we also use the code assist infrastructure. Fixed.
See bug 94965 comment 1. Verified on build I20050526-2000-win32.

Bug.Summery: [quick assist] quick assist should take upper bound of return types
[quick fix] cast quick fix should propose lower bound of parameter types
[Progress] progress view flashes even when no visible update occurs

Lines.Line: - Have a long running job (e.g. synchronize workspace)
- Open the progress view
- 'Open Type', press some filter expression
(open type schedules many system jobs to refresh the type list)

Bug.WithStack:
I20050420 with ZRH plug-ins of 0426 (take upcoming I20050426)
- Have a long running job (e.g. synchronize workspace) - Open the progress view - 'Open Type', press some filter expression (open type schedules many system jobs to refresh the type list)
> note that the progress view flashes constantly. This is probably due to the table being updated with the incoming jobs.
Expected: the table should not update itself if the created jobs are not actually displayed (system jobs). Note that the flashing also occurs if only a job's label or the progress bar is updated. *** Bug 114526 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This flashing still occurs in I20060419-1640, and really makes the progress view hard to look at on GTK. The whole view seems to flash whenever anything changes in the view. *** Bug 139059 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** A comment that I made in bug 139059 before realizing that it was a dup:
I put a println in Control.setBounds(...) and it appears that the Composite is getting a constant stream of size change requests (ie.- something like setBounds(...) or setSize(...) is being called on it). These don't seem to be needed since nothing is really getting resized here, and they're always in pairs (ie.- change the height to some value, then revert it to its previous value).
This was caused by an uneccessary resize of the control on refresh. Fixed in build >20060620 Thanks, it's much better now! I filed bug 148356 about the remaining flicker when jobs get added or removed from the list. Verified in 20060807-2000
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20050420 with ZRH plug-ins of 0426 (take upcoming I20050426)
- Have a long running job (e.g. synchronize workspace) - Open the progress view - 'Open Type', press some filter expression (open type schedules many system jobs to refresh the type list)
> note that the progress view flashes constantly. This is probably due to the table being updated with the incoming jobs.
Expected: the table should not update itself if the created jobs are not actually displayed (system jobs). Note that the flashing also occurs if only a job's label or the progress bar is updated. *** Bug 114526 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This flashing still occurs in I20060419-1640, and really makes the progress view hard to look at on GTK. The whole view seems to flash whenever anything changes in the view. *** Bug 139059 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** A comment that I made in bug 139059 before realizing that it was a dup:
I put a println in Control.setBounds(...) and it appears that the Composite is getting a constant stream of size change requests (ie.- something like setBounds(...) or setSize(...) is being called on it). These don't seem to be needed since nothing is really getting resized here, and they're always in pairs (ie.- change the height to some value, then revert it to its previous value).
This was caused by an uneccessary resize of the control on refresh. Fixed in build >20060620 Thanks, it's much better now! I filed bug 148356 about the remaining flicker when jobs get added or removed from the list. Verified in 20060807-2000

Bug.Summery: GB18030: Can't build project which contains GB18030 DBCS characters.

Lines.Line: 1. Start Eclipse, select File->New->Project....
2. In the New project dialog, select C++/Standard Make C++ Project, click Next.
3. Enter the name containing GB18030 DBCS characters(eg: unicode:6D4B,
unicode:8BD5), Click Next.
4. In the Binary Parser tab, select Elf Parser for linux in the drop down box,
click Finish.
5. Click Yes if the Confirm Perspective Switch dialog pops up.
6. In the C/C++ Projects view, right click on the project and select Import.
7. In the Import dialog,select File System. Click Next. Enter the path to
TestData/SB in the From directory: field. Click Select All then
Finish.
8. Right click on the project and select Build project.
-->Problem: The build output: "make -k clean all
make: *** No rule to make target 'clean'
make: *** No rule to make target 'all'."

Bug.WithStack:
OS: SLES9 Language: Simplified Chinese Build level: 20050418 JDK version: J2RE 1.4.2 IBM build cxia32142sr1a-20050209 (JIT enabled: jitc)
Summary: GB18030: Can't build project which contains GB18030 DBCS characters.
Steps to recreate problem: 1. Start Eclipse, select File->New->Project.... 2. In the New project dialog, select C++/Standard Make C++ Project, click Next. 3. Enter the name containing GB18030 DBCS characters(eg: unicode:6D4B, unicode:8BD5), Click Next. 4. In the Binary Parser tab, select Elf Parser for linux in the drop down box, click Finish. 5. Bug.Summery: Eclipse hangs on code assist
Bug.WithStack:
When trying to type a method for a class which is on an external jar, code assist opens. After selecting the method I want eclipse hangs.
I noticed that this problem occurs when the method is in an external jar. I also noticed that after a very long wait 10 minutes or so, it comes back.
One other thing, it seems this is related to the fill arguments... but I'm not sure. Argument filling got significantly improved, so give a try to latest build. Likely a dup of bug 86579.
Pls reopen if symptoms persist in latest, with exact steps to reproduce. Close at there's more than 1 month without any feedback on this issue => consider it does no longer happen
As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: IFile.exist() says false while IFile.create() thows exception on windows

Lines.Line: a) Create a simple project called 'Project'
b) Create a file called 'a.txt' under 'Project
c) Create IFile instance with name '/Project/A.TXT'.
d) The above IFile.exists() returns 'false' so that
the file is going to be created
e) But IFile.create(stream, true, null) throws ResourceException()
with "A resource exists with a different case" message.

Bug.WithStack:
When a file is in the project and another file which has the same name but its case is different( i.e. a.txt and A.TXT ), IFile.exist() returns false though IFile.create() throws the exception so that 'test and create' doesn't work at all to make sure that the file is actually created. Here is how to
a) Create a simple project called 'Project' b) Create a file called 'a.txt' under 'Project c) Create IFile instance with name '/Project/A.TXT'. d) The above IFile.exists() returns 'false' so that the file is going to be created e) But IFile.create(stream, true, null) throws ResourceException() with "A resource exists with a different case" message.
This inconsistent behaviour causes a problem.
The stack trace is like : org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.checkDoesNotExist(Resource.java:280) org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.File.create(File.java:107) org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.File.create(File.java:182)

Bug.Summery: Method parameters are named as "arg#", not as in the source code
Bug.WithStack:
For a method void method1(Object ob), when suspended on a breakpoint, the "Variables" view would show: "arg0= Object (id=...)", not "ob= Object (id=...)"
The most crucial thing it prevents is the inspection of expressions in the source code (via Ctrl-Shift-I'ing a selection) We show "arg1" etc., when sufficient debug attribtues not provided by the classfiles, and we cannot retrieve the names used in source. This is a known limitation and only occurrs in class files without arg name debug attribtues.
Bug.WithOutStack:
For a method void method1(Object ob), when suspended on a breakpoint, the "Variables" view would show: "arg0= Object (id=...)", not "ob= Object (id=...)"
The most crucial thing it prevents is the inspection of expressions in the source code (via Ctrl-Shift-I'ing a selection) We show "arg1" etc., when sufficient debug attribtues not provided by the classfiles, and we cannot retrieve the names used in source. This is a known limitation and only occurrs in class files without arg name debug attribtues.

Bug.Summery: StyledText: Add caret listener

Lines.Line: - The caret is at offset 50
- Calling getSelection() will return (50, 50)
- The ARROW_RIGHT key is pressed
- The caret will be moved to offset 51 as a result
- As expected, getSelection() will now return (51, 51)
- I extended Caret with StyledTextCaret
- StyledTextCaret tracks the current offset of the caret in the StyledText.
- I removed the field caretOffset and replaced it with a call to get the offset
from the StyledTextCaret

Bug.WithStack:
Currently, there does not seem to be a way of being notified by the StyledText widget when the caret position (offset) has changed.
This facility is needed in order to be able to properly update information within the client application that is dependent on the respective caret offset, for example formatting or semantic data associated with the text content at that offset. In addition to or as a result of this, there may also be UI controls that require updating and therefore rely on getting the necessary notifications. A common example of this would be a line/column indicator in the status bar.
The current workaround to achieve this is to listen for all events that may cause a change to the caret position such as key events, mouse events, selection events and modify events in addition to initiating manual updates whenever methods such as setCaretOffset are directly called on the StyledText. Not only is this clumsy and error-prone, there are also no guarantees about the exact point at which the offset change occurs in the event processing chain or whether a change occurs at all. A more robust way seems desirable.
It would be helpful if one could write something along the lines of:
styledText.addCaretListener(new CaretListener() { public void caretOffsetChanged(CaretEvent event) { // ... } });
In this scenario, a CaretEvent would be fired whenever the caret offset changes, be it due to user interaction or programmatically setting it.
For information about how Swing handles this, please see:
* javax.swing.text.JTextComponent.addCaretListener * javax.swing.event.CaretListener Some more thoughts about this issue;
Since selection in a text widget is so closely coupled with the offset of the caret, the requested functionality could perhaps be realized with the existing selection mechanism alone.
Consider the following scenario:
- The caret is at offset 50 - Calling getSelection() will return (50, 50) - The ARROW_RIGHT key is pressed - The caret will be moved to offset 51 as a result - As expected, getSelection() will now return (51, 51)
Note that even though the selection (as defined by getSelection()) has changed from (50,50) to (51,51), no selection event is fired. That in itself could be regarded as a bug but I assume that it is intentional because there is only a transition from one zero-length selection to another.
If you, however, were to include these cases in the selection event mechanism and fire an event every time the effective value of getSelection()/getSelectionRange() changes, developers would have a way of tracking changes to the caret offset since moving the caret means changing the selection (even if start==end).
Off the top of my head, I can think of three caveats:
* Due to the SWT policy for selection events, this approach would still cover only user-initiated changes, not programmatic ones. This would likely make the feature less useful and robust. * If for some reason there is a transition from a selection starting at 50 and ending at 40 to one that is starting at 40 and ending at 50, the selection objects for both would be equal (40, 50) but an event would have to be fired nevertheless because in the former case the caret is at 40 while in the latter it's at 50. * Some developers might be relying on the way selection events are currently fired, and changing this behaviour may therefore not be possible.
So what's the solution? Perhaps introducing some kind of ExtendedSelection event that has none of these problems? (You already have Modify/ExtendedModify.)
Any other ideas? is there a fix or workaround for this issue? *** Bug 256773 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I have written a patch which allows to add a listener to the caret and I'm willing to submit it here.
My solution consists of these changes:
- I extended Caret with StyledTextCaret - StyledTextCaret tracks the current offset of the caret in the StyledText. - I removed the field caretOffset and replaced it with a call to get the offset from the StyledTextCaret
Questions:
- Is it correct to extend Caret? I feel that the offset in the buffer is a universal attribute of Caret and should exist in the parent class.
- My patch doesn't fix the "selection changed" in Comment #1. Can you please open a new bug to track that one? I think it should be a small issue to fix after this patch but I don't want to mix the two.
- There are two other fields which belong to the caret: columnX and caretAlignment. I didn't have to move them for my fix but I feel that they also belong in the new class. Any comments on this?
I like Florian Priester suggestion in comment #1. I just afraid that would break things. Maybe the ExtendedSelection is the way to go.
Aaron, you can't subclass Caret - that will only cause problems. The applicaiton usually set its own caret in the StyledText what will not be an instance of your StyledTextCaret.
I'd just find the places where StyledText changes the caretOffset and make then all go thru a method that sends the event when sendEvent==true.
Since we are not keeping your subclass, you prop only have to worry about columnX and caretAlignment. (In reply to comment #5) > I like Florian Priester suggestion in comment #1. I just afraid that would > break things. Maybe the ExtendedSelection is the way to go.
Care the elaborate what you're talking about? Any pointers what ExtendedSelection is?
> Aaron, you can't subclass Caret - that will only cause problems. The > applicaiton usually set its own caret in the StyledText what will not be an > instance of your StyledTextCaret.
I was afraid of something like this. That's why I copied all the classes necessary into my project and modified them there. SWT really isn't open for any kind of resuse :( *sigh*
Okay, why do all those applicaiton set their own caret? Do you have an example?
> I'd just find the places where StyledText changes the caretOffset and > make then all go thru a method that sends the event when sendEvent==true. > > Since we are not keeping your subclass, you prop only have to worry about > columnX and caretAlignment.
I'm really unhappy to stuff more and more things into a class that already has 9000+ lines of code.
Or let me put it another way: I'm happy. I've made my changes and I'm offering to hand them back. I'm not at all interested in creating a maintenance nightmare and attach my name to it. So if you say that SWT has become so rigid that it's impossible to add missing features, the resolution to this bug will be a post in my blog with an URL to a fork of SWT. >Care the elaborate what you're talking about?
Read comment #1.
>Any pointers what ExtendedSelection is?
That would be a new event. (just like Modify has ExtendedModify).
>I was afraid of something like this. That's why I copied all the classes >necessary into my project and modified them there. SWT really isn't open for >any kind of resuse :( *sigh* >Okay, why do all those applicaiton set their own caret? Do you have an example?

Hang on there, let's not be so negative. What really matters is that we get the functionality out in a way that doesn't break people. Wanting to stop the caret from moving is a reasonable thing.
Felipe, please work with Aaron to fix this bug and/or fix it yourself. Since you are the owner of the class, you have the final say on the design and implementation. (In reply to comment #8) > Felipe, please work with Aaron to fix this bug and/or fix it yourself. Since > you are the owner of the class, you have the final say on the design and > implementation.
IMO, the best description of a solution is in comment #1. I'll work on it. > Wanting to stop the caret from moving is a reasonable thing.
Should be "track the caret movement". Stopping is interesting too, but the major requirement is tracking. Fixed in HEAD > 20081208
See StyledText#addCaretListener()
Kevin, please see this fix gets in for M4 Felipe, thanks for getting to this one! I look forward to being able to use the new API.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Currently, there does not seem to be a way of being notified by the StyledText widget when the caret position (offset) has changed.
This facility is needed in order to be able to properly update information within the client application that is dependent on the respective caret offset, for example formatting or semantic data associated with the text content at that offset. In addition to or as a result of this, there may also be UI controls that require updating and therefore rely on getting the necessary notifications. A common example of this would be a line/column indicator in the status bar.
The current workaround to achieve this is to listen for all events that may cause a change to the caret position such as key events, mouse events, selection events and modify events in addition to initiating manual updates whenever methods such as setCaretOffset are directly called on the StyledText. Not only is this clumsy and error-prone, there are also no guarantees about the exact point at which the offset change occurs in the event processing chain or whether a change occurs at all. A more robust way seems desirable.
It would be helpful if one could write something along the lines of:
styledText.addCaretListener(new CaretListener() { public void caretOffsetChanged(CaretEvent event) { // ... } });
In this scenario, a CaretEvent would be fired whenever the caret offset changes, be it due to user interaction or programmatically setting it.
For information about how Swing handles this, please see:
* javax.swing.text.JTextComponent.addCaretListener * javax.swing.event.CaretListener Some more thoughts about this issue;
Since selection in a text widget is so closely coupled with the offset of the caret, the requested functionality could perhaps be realized with the existing selection mechanism alone.
Consider the following scenario:
- The caret is at offset 50 - Calling getSelection() will return (50, 50) - The ARROW_RIGHT key is pressed - The caret will be moved to offset 51 as a result - As expected, getSelection() will now return (51, 51)
Note that even though the selection (as defined by getSelection()) has changed from (50,50) to (51,51), no selection event is fired. That in itself could be regarded as a bug but I assume that it is intentional because there is only a transition from one zero-length selection to another.
If you, however, were to include these cases in the selection event mechanism and fire an event every time the effective value of getSelection()/getSelectionRange() changes, developers would have a way of tracking changes to the caret offset since moving the caret means changing the selection (even if start==end).
Off the top of my head, I can think of three caveats:
* Due to the SWT policy for selection events, this approach would still cover only user-initiated changes, not programmatic ones. This would likely make the feature less useful and robust. * If for some reason there is a transition from a selection starting at 50 and ending at 40 to one that is starting at 40 and ending at 50, the selection objects for both would be equal (40, 50) but an event would have to be fired nevertheless because in the former case the caret is at 40 while in the latter it's at 50. * Some developers might be relying on the way selection events are currently fired, and changing this behaviour may therefore not be possible.
So what's the solution? Perhaps introducing some kind of ExtendedSelection event that has none of these problems? (You already have Modify/ExtendedModify.)
Any other ideas? is there a fix or workaround for this issue? *** Bug 256773 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I have written a patch which allows to add a listener to the caret and I'm willing to submit it here.
My solution consists of these changes:
- I extended Caret with StyledTextCaret - StyledTextCaret tracks the current offset of the caret in the StyledText. - I removed the field caretOffset and replaced it with a call to get the offset from the StyledTextCaret
Questions:
- Is it correct to extend Caret? I feel that the offset in the buffer is a universal attribute of Caret and should exist in the parent class.
- My patch doesn't fix the "selection changed" in Comment #1. Can you please open a new bug to track that one? I think it should be a small issue to fix after this patch but I don't want to mix the two.
- There are two other fields which belong to the caret: columnX and caretAlignment. I didn't have to move them for my fix but I feel that they also belong in the new class. Any comments on this?
I like Florian Priester suggestion in comment #1. I just afraid that would break things. Maybe the ExtendedSelection is the way to go.
Aaron, you can't subclass Caret - that will only cause problems. The applicaiton usually set its own caret in the StyledText what will not be an instance of your StyledTextCaret.
I'd just find the places where StyledText changes the caretOffset and make then all go thru a method that sends the event when sendEvent==true.
Since we are not keeping your subclass, you prop only have to worry about columnX and caretAlignment. (In reply to comment #5) > I like Florian Priester suggestion in comment #1. I just afraid that would > break things. Maybe the ExtendedSelection is the way to go.
Care the elaborate what you're talking about? Any pointers what ExtendedSelection is?
> Aaron, you can't subclass Caret - that will only cause problems. The > applicaiton usually set its own caret in the StyledText what will not be an > instance of your StyledTextCaret.
I was afraid of something like this. That's why I copied all the classes necessary into my project and modified them there. SWT really isn't open for any kind of resuse :( *sigh*

> I'd just find the places where StyledText changes the caretOffset and > make then all go thru a method that sends the event when sendEvent==true. > > Since we are not keeping your subclass, you prop only have to worry about > columnX and caretAlignment.

So if you say that SWT has become so rigid that it's impossible to add missing features, the resolution to this bug will be a post in my blog with an URL to a fork of SWT. >Care the elaborate what you're talking about?

Bug.Summery: [validation] DTD Validator reports valid when the last end marker is missing

Lines.Line: 1- Select File -> New -> Other -> Examples -> Editing and Validating XML files
2- Try to break the Invoice.dtd file by deleting the end marker ">", for
example, then save
3- Right click the Invoice.dtd file and select the "Validate DTD File"

Bug.WithStack:
OS: winXP Build level: WTP-sdk-I20050422 JDK version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 SP1a
Summary: DTD validator does not work
Steps to recreate problem: 1- Select File -> New -> Other -> Examples -> Editing and Validating XML files 2- Try to break the Invoice.dtd file by deleting the end marker ">", for example, then save 3- Right click the Invoice.dtd file and select the "Validate DTD File"
Error: No message popup or displayed in Problems view to show that the DTD file is not valid.
Expected Result: A message like "The DTD file is not valid. See the problems view for a list of the validation errors" displayed when manually invoking the DTD Validator, as XML Validator. Hi Karen, can you assign this bug to lmandel@ca.ibm.com? Thanks. Reassigning this bug per Jeffrey's request Moving to the DTD component, since it provides the DTD validator. Karen, I can only reproduce this problem by removing the very last '>' in the file. If I change the last line to <!ELEMENT Year (#PCDATA) I get no error. Removing any other '>' in the file produces an error. Is this the same behaviour you're seeing? Hi Lawrence,
After further investigation, I found two problems here.
The one I previously reported occurs when I use a project name which contains DBCS characters and a "space". In this case, DTD validator does not report any result, no matter the .dtd is valid or not. This problem also occurs when a .dtd file is located under a directory name which contains DBCS characters and a "space". There is no this problem when I use an English project name with a space. Therefore, this looks to be a DBCS only issue.
The other problem is what you observed. DTD reports valid when the last end marker is missing.
Please let me know if more infomation needed. Thanks. Karen, you've now identified two separate issues. Please open a new defect for the DBCS problem and attach a sample problem file with DBCS characters and a space in the filename. Hi Lawrence,
Thanks for your advice. Bug 94088 has been opened for the DBCS issue.
Changed Version field given new release numbering.
Changing version to unspecified. Whoops! Changing version back to 0.7. Nitin, over to you. Targeting for 3.2 for investigation.

Bug.Summery: Search keyboard shortcut is wrong
Bug.WithStack:
Build I20050401-1645
The "Search" keyboard shortcut in the build is bound to command-H, which hides eclipse. It was previously bound to control-H.
Command-H with a modifier such as shift or option would work well. Markus, can you please fix this. I think this got introduced when we cleaned-up the plugin.xml file. I think this change was accidentially introduced in 1.74.
Dani, could you please apply the patch I'll append (reverts to Ctrl+H)? Created attachment 20368 Patch for org.eclipse.search Fixed. verified by David Saff on I20050509-2010
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build I20050401-1645
The "Search" keyboard shortcut in the build is bound to command-H, which hides eclipse. It was previously bound to control-H.
Command-H with a modifier such as shift or option would work well. Markus, can you please fix this. I think this got introduced when we cleaned-up the plugin.xml file. I think this change was accidentially introduced in 1.74.
Dani, could you please apply the patch I'll append (reverts to Ctrl+H)? Created attachment 20368 Patch for org.eclipse.search Fixed. verified by David Saff on I20050509-2010

Bug.Summery: DOM indexer misses some obvious symbols
Bug.WithStack: If I have a standard make project with one file -- this file does only an #include <stdio.h>, then the DOM indexer will not have a defn of printf. The old indexer will. (note that you need to build the project so that the scanner config will run - the build does not need to succeed.) Fixed calculation of file locations for names inside macro definitions.
Bug.WithOutStack: If I have a standard make project with one file -- this file does only an #include <stdio.h>, then the DOM indexer will not have a defn of printf. The old indexer will. (note that you need to build the project so that the scanner config will run - the build does not need to succeed.) Fixed calculation of file locations for names inside macro definitions.

at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:1570) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runUI(Workbench.java:1534) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.createAndRunWorkbench(Workbench.java:306) at org.eclipse.ui.PlatformUI.createAndRunWorkbench(PlatformUI.java:143) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.IDEApplication.run(IDEApplication.java:103) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator$1.run(PlatformActivator.java:228) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:344) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:156) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:85) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:58) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:60) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:391) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:319) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:272) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:951) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:935) A contribution item without a parent element? Guh? How can this happen... The fix for Bug 80569 is a likely candidate. It adds a line "item.setParent(null)" to ContributionManager. However, "getParent()" on ContributionItem is specified as not returning null. This appears to break our API contract. getParent() could always return null. The spec needs to be clarified. I've filed bug 92777 for this.
This could also explain the leak we were seeing before... if an item is removed from its parent, its dispose method would never be called. Since we're unhooking the activity listener in dispose, then we'd leak the contribution item as well as its associated action (and potentially god knows what else that's hanging off of the action).
I can easily unhook the listener when parent is set to null but this doesn't solve the problem of an un-disposed action. I've fixed the NPE and the leaking of contribution items. For the context menu case I think it's possible that we can optimize this further. I will enter a seperate report for that optimization. Verified in I20050509-2010
Bug.WithOutStack:
Version: 3.1.0 Build id: I20050420-1200
- open eclipse on an existing workspace with existing CVS connections and projects loaded. - turn off Team capabilities - went to CVS Respositories perspective and found that I could not checkout a project (forgot that i had turned the capability off) - went to File > New > Project and clicked on show all (thinking CVS would show up and enable CVS at the same time) - NPE
!ENTRY org.eclipse.jface 4 0 2005-04-26 09:48:09.562 !MESSAGE java.lang.NullPointerException !STACK 0
A contribution item without a parent element? Guh? How can this happen... The fix for Bug 80569 is a likely candidate. It adds a line "item.setParent(null)" to ContributionManager. However, "getParent()" on ContributionItem is specified as not returning null. This appears to break our API contract. getParent() could always return null. The spec needs to be clarified. I've filed bug 92777 for this.
This could also explain the leak we were seeing before... if an item is removed from its parent, its dispose method would never be called. Since we're unhooking the activity listener in dispose, then we'd leak the contribution item as well as its associated action (and potentially god knows what else that's hanging off of the action).
I can easily unhook the listener when parent is set to null but this doesn't solve the problem of an un-disposed action. I've fixed the NPE and the leaking of contribution items. For the context menu case I think it's possible that we can optimize this further. I will enter a seperate report for that optimization. Verified in I20050509-2010

Bug.Summery: J2ee Module structure problems
